bibl.title: The Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion. (1861–65.)
bibl.editor: Surgeon General Joseph K. Barnes, United States Army

taxonomy.bibl: Medical and Surgical History of the War of the Rebellion

keywords.term: wounds and injuries of the chest
remarkable lodgement of foreign bodies on post-mortem
ball buried in soft tissues and encysted

revisionDesc.change: additional proofing of transcription and encoding
case text extracted and transformed from larger file
initial checking of OCR text against PDF; encoded

body.p: CASE 25.—Private H. Millineth, Co. E, 9th New York Zouaves, was wounded at Roanoke Island, February 8th, 1862, by a round musket ball, which entered beneath the anterior convexity of the clavicle and buried itself in the soft tissues. The wound healed without trouble, the ball becoming encysted. Millineth entered Armory Square Hospital, at Washington, a year afterward, with typhoid fever. When convalescent, the ball was detected in the supra scapular suprascapular fossa, and was excised, April 28th, 1863. The man was discharged, well, May 4th, 1863, on the expiration of his term of service. Surgeon D. W. Bliss, U. S. V., presented the specimen, figured in the wood-cut (FIG. 296).

figure.head: FIG. 296.—Round ball extracted from supra scapular suprascapular fossa, fourteen months after injury. Spec. 4488, Sect. I, A. M. M.
